issue.title: EmptyConstraint - allow null string

body: @jhamm oh yes, you're right! It should be `Is.Not.Null.And.Not.Empty`. But still there is a bug with throwing `System.ArgumentException` instead of `NUnit.Framework.AssertionException` when `null` is passed.

@Robot1que It's not a bug, in that the constraint is defined to require non-null in its argument. As the message with the exception says "Requires non-null string... etc."

However, it's possible that was not a good decision on our part. Is there a reason to be passing a null to Empty?

I get that. But I'm asking for a deeper reason... that is, why would you want to do that?

Clearly, you don't want to write `Assert.That(null, Is.Empty)` since that's silly. So what kinds of real-world situations come up where you want to test a null to see if it's an empty string?
@jhamm, wouldn't it be more semantically correct to test that as `Is.Null.Or.Empty`?

Yes, if method knows the type than it correctly throws `NUnit.Framework.AssertionException`. And yes, usually actual value is a variable or property with a known type. So it was my mistake.

The only problem (or misunderstanding) left is that `Assert.That((string)null, Is.Empty)` throws `System.ArgumentException`. Still I would expect to get `AssertionException` because logically the actual value doesn't match expectation and it's a requirement mismatch which means that potentially it should be handled by test-runner in a special way.

My expectation is that Is.Empty and Is.Not.Empty would behave the same as `actual == string.Empty` and `actual != string.Empty`. These do not throw an ArgumentException and they return false then true.

When using the equalivent EmptyConstraint comparisons for the same inputs, both throw ArgumentException indicating that the null string cannot be compared.

Except that Is.Empty is not the equivalent of equality. Compare these two statements:

``` C#
Assert.That(null, Is.EqualTo(string.Empty));
Assert.IsEmpty(null);
```

The first matches the behavior of the `==` operator, just as the name of the constraint would suggest. The second is basically it's own thing, with it's own definition and it's own constraints. That's not to say we can't discuss what that definition ought to be, but just that it has nothing to do with equality.

EmptyConstraint is basically an adapter that selects one of three constraints: EmptyStringConstraint, EmptyDirectoryConstraint, EmptyCollectionConstraint. Of the three, only the first one is even close to an equality test. When designing the behavior of EmptyConstraint, I decided that it's argument should meet the needs of all the alternatives. Null definitely does not work for directories or collections. In case it's not obvious why, those two have to throw an exception because, if they simply failed, NotConstraint(EmptyDirectoryConstraint()) would succeed, possibly leading one to think that they have a non-empty directory when what they have is a null. This rule of throwing rather than failing is followed pretty uniformly throughout NUnit.

I grant that it is a reasonable option to allow a null **string** to be handled correctly. But we can't uniformly accept null for all of the three alternatives for which Empty is used. Note that we don't know which of the three actual constraints will be used until after we have an actual value.
I see you point. Right now I don't have an opinion either way, so I will defer to your vision on this one.

One possibility would be to treat unqualified null as a string and do the comparison. But even that might be a misleading result if one didn't expect it.

I don't think we can really decide without some actual use cases. Since you would never actually use a manifest null as the actual value in any assertion (except to test assert), what would be an example of an actual use of Is.Empty, where an unqualified null should be accepted?

To be clear, I am OK with accepting a typed null and acting accordingly. It would have to be typed as a string, IEnumerable or DirectoryInfo to avoid an argument exception.
@rprouse What's your take on how this ought to work? Should we move back to the PR and evaluate what it actually is doing?

I don't like that `Assert.That((string)null, Is.Not.Empty)` throws `System.ArgumentException`, but I don't want to add behaviour where a null string is considered an empty string. 

So, IMHO, the above assert should fail by throwing an AssertException with a message something like "Expected an empty string but was null".

> My expectation is that Is.Empty and Is.Not.Empty would behave the same as `actual == string.Empty` and `actual != string.Empty`. These do not throw an ArgumentException and they return false then true.

Like @CharliePoole, I don't think this is a valid example. We are not testing equality, we are testing if the string is empty.

So, my call is that we should be able to pass in a typed null and get a valid failure, not an ArgumentException. I need to review the code again, but I think it is close to that now isn't it?
